title: Sources
text:
This project uses publicly available data from the American Community Survey (ACS) 5-year estimates (2019â€“2023), provided by the U.S. Census Bureau.
We accessed this data using the tidycensus R package. Key variables include:

DP02_0152P: Percent of households with a broadband internet subscription

B19013_001: Median household income

DP05_0077P: Percent of population identifying as White

DP02_0067P: Percent of adults with a bachelorâ€™s degree

DP02_0057P: Percent of individuals currently enrolled in school

Data was retrieved programmatically using the Census API.

title: Digital Inequality in U.S. Broadband Access
text: Broadband internet access across U.S. counties varies significantly with income, race, and education levels. Using data from the U.S. Census Bureauâ€™s American Community Survey (ACS) 5-year estimates for 2023, I examined county-level variation in broadband access, median household income, racial composition, and educational attainment across the United States. The raw data were retrieved via the tidycensus R package and cleaned to create a wide-format dataset with one row per county and five key socioeconomic indicators. We modeled broadband access as a linear function of median household income, racial composition, and levels of education. Counties with higher income tended to have significantly greater broadband coverage, even after accounting for racial and educational differences. A $1,000 increase in median income is associated with a 2.4% increase in broadband access, even after controlling for other factors.

title: About
text:
Author is a Lecturer in Computer Science with a Masterâ€™s degree in Computer Science from Pakistan. I am new to Data Science but highly motivated to pursue it for my PhD studies. You can reach me via GitHub or by email at umaira.nazar09@gmail.com.
This project examines how broadband access across U.S. counties relates to income, race, and education levels using census data and statistical modeling. The full project is available on GitHub.
This project was created as a part of Kaneâ€™s Data Science Bootcamp.

title: Modeling Broadband Access
text:
To better understand the factors influencing broadband access across U.S. counties, we developed a linear regression model. The outcome variable is the percentage of households with broadband internet subscriptions. The model includes four key predictors:

Median household income (in thousands of dollars),
Percentage of the population identifying as White,
Percentage of adults with a bachelorâ€™s degree, and
Percentage of individuals currently enrolled in school.



\[
\text{Broadband Access} = \beta_0 + \beta_1 \cdot \text{Income} + \beta_2 \cdot \text{White} + \beta_3 \cdot \text{Bachelor's Degree} + \beta_4 \cdot \text{School Enrollment} + \epsilon
\]






Call:
lm(formula = broadband_total ~ median_income_k + pct_white + 
    pct_bachelor + pct_enrolled, data = acs_clean)

Residuals:
    Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
-223116  -34635  -12187    9873 3251913 

Coefficients:
                Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
(Intercept)     195435.9    44400.6   4.402 1.11e-05 ***
median_income_k   2414.2      142.4  16.959  < 2e-16 ***
pct_white          511.3      201.3   2.540   0.0111 *  
pct_bachelor     -2633.6      514.5  -5.118 3.27e-07 ***
pct_enrolled     -3534.8      444.5  -7.952 2.54e-15 ***
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

Residual standard error: 115500 on 3135 degrees of freedom
Multiple R-squared:  0.1198,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.1186 
F-statistic: 106.6 on 4 and 3135 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16
